Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; lotus flower and palmette chain in added red and added white, above zigzag band between white and red lines; top of lip glazed; exterior: short diagonal strokes (or long dots) between lines at rim; below, painted decoration consisting of two confronted sphinxes (of left sphinx, only face with white flesh remaining; of right sphinx, only white face, hair divided into three tresses with red, curlicue, elaborate earring, chest and part of wing remaining).
Curator's comments: Lemos places this sherd with the Chalice Style, but there are a number of features that would suggest that the vase might be better placed within the Grand Style. In the first instance, the interior decoration is very elaborate for the Chalice Style, but typical for the Grand Style. Secondly, the rim pattern decoration is also commonly found in the Grand Style. Thirdly, whilst sphinxes are not a typical figure found on Grand Style vessels, the use of white for flesh is connected with the Grand Style. For parallels regarding the interior decoration, rim pattern and white for flesh, see British Museum 1888,0601.508. See also 1886,0401.1549 and 1888,0601.500.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 292, no. 901, pl. 120)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 140, no. 792, pl. 96)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0722) (phase 2)
